overview: This subject builds on the knowledge gained in Nursing Science 1 and examines the pathophysiology of different body systems. The common conditions that alter skin, the nervous system, cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, endocrine, musculo-skeletal and genitourinary and reproductive systems will be examined. Students will add to their knowledge of drugs by examining the physiological action of selected subcutaneous, intramuscular and intravenous medications.
intended learning outcomes: Describe and discuss the pathophysiology of common disorders that affect the skin, the nervous system (including special senses), cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, endocrine, musculoskeletal, genitourinary and reproductive systems
Identify the occurrence of common pathological processes across the lifespan; among children, adolescents, older adults within the Indigenous and non-Indigenous community
Identify the differences in prevalence of disease/risk factors for Indigenous and non-indigenous population
Discuss the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of selected subcutaneous, intramuscular and intravenous medications including medications used during, pre- and post- surgical procedures
Develop understanding of the patient care plans with applied pathophysiology, clinical investigations and pharmacology and in accordance with relevant policies/ guidelines

additional pre-requisite: (or the pre-2019 version of this subject NURS50003 Nursing Science 1)

assessments.description: Case study 1 analysis - online activity. 500 words
Case study 2 analysis - online activity. 1000 words
Case study 3 analysis - online activity. 1000 words
Written examination. 2 hours. Hurdle requirement:. Students must pass the 2-hour written examination to pass the subject

McCance, K. & Huether, S. (2019). Pathophysiology: The biologic basis for disease in adults and children (8th ed).  St. Louis: Elsevier Mosby.
